'''Kalimban''' was the name of a region in the [[Great Lands]], later known as [[wikipedia:Germany|Germany]], according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] associated with ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.<ref name="Kal"/> 

Its inhabitants were known as '''''Kalimbardi''''' (i.e. [[wikipedia:Germans|Germans]]).<ref name="Kal">{{PE|12}}, p. 44</ref>

== Etymology ==
The name ''Kalimban'' is in [[Qenya]], glossed as "Barbary, Germany", being an elaboration on ''[[Kalimbo (Qenya word)|kalimbo]]'' ("barbarian").<ref>{{webcite|author=[[Paul Strack]]|articleurl=http://eldamo.org/content/words/word-3647029151.html|articlename=ᴱQ. ''Kalimban'' loc.|website=Eldamo|accessed=1 May 2022}}</ref>

''Kalimbardi'' was probably composed of ''kalimbo'' + ''[[mardo]]'' ("dweller").<ref>{{webcite|author=[[Paul Strack]]|articleurl=http://eldamo.org/content/words/word-595017667.html|articlename=ᴱQ. ''Kalimbardi'' coll.|website=Eldamo|accessed=1 May 2022}}</ref>

== Inspiration ==
The unflattering associations of Germany and the German people with barbarism were written by [[Tolkien]] during the [[wikipedia:World War I|World War I]], in which it wasn't uncommon for the English people and military to characterize their enemy as being savage and inhuman.<ref>[[John Garth]], ''[[Tolkien and the Great War]]'', "Part One: The immortal four", ''6. Too long in slumber'', pp. 128-9</ref>
